user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskRegister_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskRegister_Impl(osal_id_t global_task_id)
{
    int32                    return_code;
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t arg;
    int                      old_state;
    int                      old_type;

    /*
     * Set cancel state=ENABLED, type=DEFERRED
     * This should be the default for new threads, but
     * setting explicitly to be sure that a pthread_join()
     * will work as expected in case this thread is deleted.
     */
    pthread_setcancelstate(PTHREAD_CANCEL_ENABLE, &old_state);
    pthread_setcanceltype(PTHREAD_CANCEL_DEFERRED, &old_type);

    memset(&arg, 0, sizeof(arg));

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    arg.id = global_task_id;

    return_code = pthread_setspecific(POSIX_GlobalVars.ThreadKey, arg.opaque_arg);
    if (return_code == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("OS_TaskRegister_Impl failed during pthread_setspecific() error=%s\n", strerror(return_code));
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskRegister_Impl:
typedef union
{
    void *           opaque_arg;
    OS_ArgCallback_t arg_callback_func;
    osal_id_t        id;
    osal_index_t     idx;
} OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
explanation: Only the fragments listed above need further investigation with respect to unreachable code. The remaining parts of the function are plain declarations, comments, and normal control-flow constructs (variable declarations, the function prologue/epilogue, and the final return) and do not themselves create unreachable code. The OS_DEBUG macro is defined empty and therefore does not introduce unreachable code (it only elides logging). The union usage (memset followed by assigning to a union member and later reading a different union member) may be a correctness/aliasing concern but does not by itself produce unreachable code. There are no early return statements or conditional compilation branches elsewhere in this function that would render subsequent lines unreachable, so no other fragments need investigation for Rule 2.1.
